titleStmt.title: Revisions to Henry David Thoreau's manuscript of Walden

publicationStmt.p: Final Project for ENGL 340, Literature and Literary Study in the Digital Age, Spring 2024, SUNY Geneseo.

sourceDesc.bibl: Transcriptions from HM 924, the manuscript of Walden:

zone.line: When I came to build my
chimney I studied masonry.
My bricks being second-hand
ones required to be cleaned with
a trowel, so that I learned more
than usual of the qualities of
bricks and trowels. The mortar on
them was fifty years old, and
was said to be still growing harder;
but this is one of those sayings
which men love to repeat whether
they are true or not.
Such sayings themselves grow harder and adhere more
firmly with age, and it would take
many blows of a trowel and clean
an old wise-acre of them. Many
of the villages of Mesopotamia
are said to be built of very good quality, ob-
tained from the ruins of Babylon,
and the cement on the is older
and probably harder still. However that may be, I
was struck by the peculiar
toughness of the steel which
bore so many violent blows
without being worn out.

I filled the spaces between, the bricks
about the fire place with stones from
the land shore, and also made my
mortar with the white sand from
the same place. Some white and
cleaner sand for plastering I brought
over from the opposite shore in a boat
several cartloads at once together with my
spade and barrow, and I was very
glad to avail myself of this sort
of conveyance - a highway that never
needs to be mended - and over which
you pass with the heaviest loads
without a jar or a scar.
I have thus a tight shingled and plastered house 10 feet wide by 15 long and
8 feet high - with a garret and a closet,
a large window on each side - two
trap doors, one door at the end,
and a brick fire place opposite.
The exact cost of my house, when
completed, paying the usual price for
the materials, and not counting
the work all of which was done.
